displayed_text: Patient: I think that’s probably his standard of care that he has to follow up, but if you’re following up - Doctor: Well, I would keep the appointment with him in January. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And, then, maybe after that I could see you in April and if it turns out in January, your PSA has, you know, gone - instead of continuing to go south, it’s gone north, or we may, we may need to switch treatments whatever, then I would, I would maybe see you sooner to discuss that. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, I, why don’t I - I’m going to make the appointment, I think, part of this appointment this January and, uh, I’m not sure if he’s doing the six-month injection, but, um, I’ll make an appointment for, it’s says April sixteenth. I’ll just make it April seventeenth which is a Tuesday. And, you don’t have to see him; you just see me. Family Member: Not the sixteenth? Doctor: I’ll e-mail him, but you can also tell him at the next appointment. Patient: I will. Doctor: You think it’s best – does he think it’s a good idea? He and I do this all the time. We, we transition after he’s finished with the radiation part. Because, unless - I mean, he’s not going away. We might need him again. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Down the road maybe. I don’t know. I hope not. But, but, but I think in terms of talking about the next trials, all those kinds of things, you need to be with, you’re going to, that’s going to be me. Okay?

Family Member: Is that what they did to him before when he went down there? They - Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Where the pain, where the pain was? Doctor: Uh hum, well there, they radiated you from the outside. You laid down and they beamed it to you, right. This is internal. So when they push it in your bloodstream it goes all around and it lands in the area of the bone that has the cancer. Family Member: Is there side effects? Doctor: Oh yeah, there’s always side effects. Because it’s radiation, some of the side effects could be you know reduced or lower amounts of blood cells in your system, so people could get low white cells, red cells, platelets. Those are your three guys that I always watch out for and in some people, it’s a pretty big dip and you don’t come back. Very rare, but it’s a possibility. Family Member: What do you mean a dip? Doctor: Meaning it destroys too much. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: And there’s no coming back. But you know in terms of how much does that occur, it’s very rare. Could it occur—sure, and I tend to see it in folks who have had a lot of therapy, especially chemo. You’ve had pills and more pills, a little smattering of radiation and a Provenge, and a partridge in a pear tree. So where you are coming in is your bone marrow is not as compromised as a person who had chemo. I’m not saying that you couldn’t get it after chemo, but the perfect person to give it in is a person who is actually having some pain, which you are, a person that otherwise is in good shape, and has a good enough bone marrow reserve, which you do, and it’s not related to any other treatment like steroids and things like that, where if I were to offer chemo, that would be part of the package. Again, not impossible for us to go down the chemo route, but that’s also the next discussion. But for this, I think it’s reasonable to talk to the radiation doctor about it because you’ll want to know pros and cons. So the bone marrow is the thing I always worry about, but for my other patients, and I’ve had many go through it, the other part that it could affect would be your gut. So diarrhea, stomach upset, not so much nausea and vomiting but just more like you know you’ve got the poops kind of thing. But for you it’s obviously something we could regulate because you could get Imodium, you know. You could get treatment. A lot of my patients have it during the time around you know the week that you get injected and then nothing else. So that’s kind of where it is. Oh, and if you have cancer that’s not in the bone, like liver or lungs, which you don’t have, but those patients, they don’t; you know they shouldn’t be treated with this medicine because that medicine that I’m thinking about for you is only for bone. So it will not go to liver or anywhere else. Family Member: So the pain that he’s having - Doctor: Is in bone. Family Member: And how big of a spot does he have there – on his hip and lower leg, upper leg.

Family Member: Xofigo. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Do you think he’s qualified to go away on a vacation for a couple of weeks? Doctor: Uh hum, yeah – when are you going? Healthcare Professional: When are you going on vacation? Doctor: Yeah, I get to go. Family Member: February fifth till – Doctor: Oh yeah, because even if you start in January, it’s monthly, so. Family Member: So February fifth till like the twenty, till like the twenty-second or something. Doctor: Oh that’s fine. That’s fine. Family Member: So we have to schedule that around then. Doctor: Oh yeah, he’ll, trust me, we will hunt you down. He will hunt you down because every time you’re about to get a dose, it’s fifteen thousand dollars a dose.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the reason I’m mentioning that is because a lot of patients do want to go on this therapy without being on the Lupron at the same time or a similar drug. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And the way that the trial is designed, if you give the testosterone without concurrently at the same time, suppressing the testosterone as well, then you don’t achieve these opposites between very high and very low levels. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: What happens is over time is the testosterone just keeps increasing and increasing and increasing, and eventually it will begin to feed the cancer, at least in theory. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So that is why we give both drugs in combination. And what happens is on a monthly basis through about twenty-eight day treatment cycles the testosterone goes from being super-high, much higher than your body would be able to make on its own back down to super-low. PAT Uh huh. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So every twenty-eight days which is roughly every four weeks, your testosterone will spike for a few days and then within about a week it will drop down to the very low levels. Patient: When you say spike, what numbers have you seen? Doctor: Right, so I told you before that a real low testosterone level for someone your age might be let’s say a hundred fifty to two hundred milligrams per deciliter. Here, they’re talking about between one thousand and one thousand five hundred milligrams per deciliter. So it’s a five- to ten-fold increase above the physiological level. So we call this super-physiological. That means higher than physiological.

Patient: I’m gonna have to, you know? I’m - Doctor: Do you have the latest list? Did you give it to K____ or is it the same list from before? Patient: Same as before. Doctor: Same as before. Okay. Patient: Yeah. We’re all good. || Good seeing ya. Doctor: Good seeing you too. Alright I will have - Patient: Congratulations on your cert. Doctor: Thank you. I’ll have M____ come in in just a sec. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: Alright.

Patient: Because he went on to say he says in that area… Doctor: Um hum. Patient: …and we probably will be looking at some radiation. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: And you know me, or like anyone, you’re going through the chemo and stuff like that you want… Doctor: Yeah. You’re like whaaaat? Patient: You want the golden ring man. Doctor: I got ya. Patient: You want that stuff to be doing everything it’s supposed to do. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Well it is doing everything it’s supposed to do because if you look at your lymph node, remember the bones hardly ever change. Patient: Right. Doctor: So whether it’s up or down, I just want to know if it’s new.

Family Member: Oh. Doctor: It looked like they should be in a catalog. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So, I wasn’t sure if it was like Tigers day or. Family Member: I know. Yes. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Just working zone. (Laughter) Doctor: How you feeling? Patient: I’ve been great. Doctor: The rest of your labs are fine, but, you know, your PSA is trickling up, four point two. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Now, in March, you were at two and a half. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Hey! I want to know. Doctor: Okay. So, there’s a gene called BRCA2 which is – Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Associated with prostate and breast cancer. I’ll write it down for you. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Um, that your – you have a mutation that you’ve inherited. What does that mean? Um. Well, we know that BRCA2 can be, um, a predisposition to getting prostate cancer. Patient: Well, I should tell you that -- I think it happened since I saw you – my brother was diagnosed. Doctor: With prostate cancer also? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Yeah. You’re one – Patient: Now, his scans came back --- bone scan and CAT scan came back, uh, uh, what do you call it? Negative. Positive? Nothing wrong which – Doctor: Now, remind me again, your children? How many children do you have? Patient: He is five years older.

Patient: Uh I have to tell Dr. C____, but I’m gonna go for it. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. Patient: I need to make an appointment with him and do the uh. Doctor: For the scope and all that. Patient: Scope. Doctor: So he makes sure the passage is okay and the bladder is safe and all that. Alright so I’ll let them know if you’re okay with it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay and uh then we’ll plan for your appointment after the cryo and everything is done. So forget about the June appointment. We’ll just schedule something later on. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay because probably the whole month of June will be taken up so most likely it will be somewhere end of July or so. Okay? Patient: So how do I make the appointment for the scope? Doctor: Yeah I’m gonna tell them so the scheduler will hook you up or J the nurse will talk to the scheduler. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Every time I go in… Doctor: You just go and get your injection? Patient: Yeah and I think it would be better off do everything here. Doctor: Okay. Well I’m just wondering then if we should hold off and uh because we may have to switch him to Firmagon if he’s not getting enough suppression. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, okay. Doctor: Okay so why don’t you hold off on the injection tomorrow. Patient: Don’t take it tomorrow? Doctor: Don’t take it tomorrow. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let me see what your testosterone level is and I’m going to put in for a different injection. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Unfortunately that means it’ll have to be a monthly shot, but you know we may have to do that if your testosterone is not suppressed. Because if the Lupron is not working for you…

Family Member: Alright. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Thank you for your time! Patient: Thanks for your time! Doctor: Good to see you. Huh? Family Member: Good to see you. Other than that, Doctor: Yeah. I think she’s got a questionnaire or two for you. Okay. I’ll let A_ know. Patient: Now, you’re gonna, now they’re gonna check the pharmacy and let me know? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I have to – I give it to our pharmacist, and then she’ll start processing it. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Right. Doctor: To see if we can use predictive algorithms. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Ah as well as additional diagnostic testing to help them with that kind of decision making process whether to pursue radiation therapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Ah early after their surgical therapy versus just kind of holding tight (coughs) Patient: As a preemptive strike? Doctor: Correct. Patient: Oh. Doctor: As a preemptive strike kind of to mop up any residual- Patient: Right. Doctor: -cancer that may be remaining or viable within the field. Patient: Okay.

Patient: You are? Doctor: Yeah. Why have it be a mystery. Because if you do call me, guess what I’m gonna say? Hey Mr. you need to get an x-ray. So I’m gonna bypass that question… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …and we’re just gonna see what it is. Patient: So you’re, you’re thinking Doctor: Yeah. Patient: it I mean an x-ray to look at it that may be even a replacement here or something’s been compromised here or the cancer side? Doctor: Well yeah or if it’s just arthritis then we often just… Patient: I see. Doctor: … we can all just be happy or Patient: Okay. Doctor: At some point you’ll probably get a knee-hip replacement.

Family Member: Gotcha. Doctor: That’s the problem. Patient: I’m not eating less. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I do feel that I’m eating better… Um… Family Member: Mhmm. Doctor: Yeah because you got a week off. Patient: Pardon? Family Member: Oh no. (laughs) Patient: Oh no, no. My, my uh… My appetite has never been affected by this medication. Doctor: Okay. Alright. Patient: I do notice one thing while I was off. I I can feel the difference in the energy level. Doctor: Yeah. Which is probably not helping me having you drink more because then you’re just more active and on the go.

Family Member: Ahhhh. Doctor: We can get a PSA. If that PSA is higher than what we have, then R_ will sort of talk to you about coming back down to get some of this other stuff. So, we’ll be watching you behind the scenes – Family Member: Uh, huh. Doctor: To sort of figure out when’s the right time for you to come back. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Got it. Patient: So, the first thing is to, uh, see if I can come up (healthy) Doctor: Yeah. Just to see, yeah, how much it’s gonna cost ya. (Pause) Family Member: Okay. Patient: I think last time I was on the Xtandi, they wanted to know if I have any income to speak of or – Doctor: Yeah. They’ll do the wallet check and everything. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If they think you make enough money that you should be able to pay for it, then they’re not gonna give you one of these, uh, uh, grants.
